July 4?. 85
Dear Papa!
I thought that I would
write an english letter to
you once so that I would
not get all out of practice.
Mama received your letters 
just now & the ticket and
she said that we might make
use of the ticket this
afternoon.  Yesterday it
was 92 degrees in the shade,
but we had a shower in 
the night that cooled it off
a little.  It is very rainy
to-day & it is only 80

degrees - I can't say that it is
only 80 degrees in the shade,
for there is no sunshine.
Mr. Bloch brought two games 
from Milwaukee, which are
something like parcheesei; &
are to be cast to lot when
we are going home.  We got
some new boarders yesterday,
but have not, as yet; made
their acquaintance.  The house 
seems very quiet, (when) because
the Rehms & Leichts are gone,
although there are enough
children left to play with.
Charlie Freund went away
Monday morning & that makes
one more less.  Auntie had
headache again yesterday; so
did mamma & I, but it
was of no consequence, and

I think every body had a 
headache yesterday, it was
so hot.  Eddie is going to
Milwaukee this afternoon
with the big boys of
Petersen's.  Yesterday night
we were just dancing in the
hall where we always
dance, when a terrible storm
came up; blowing
the sands into the
open windows & (b) pretty
near blowing out the 
lights.  We all ran to 
the house, in wild confu-
sion & when we arrived
there we were half cho-
ked with sand.
Many regards from all for 
you &the girls.  
Your 
Annie

NOTES
Annie to her father H R.
Sumer 1885
Annie mentions she is
returning The "pass"
So he can use it to come
on Saturday, The pass is 
on the railroad (newspaper
unclear there)

Because Annie had no time to write yesterday or today I am sending you the letter she wrote Saturday without help or dictation or corrections.  (Herman Raster's note)
Probably about 1880 or so -
old? letter unclear used from time
H.R. was Collector of Internal
Revenue in Chicago

Mr. H Raster Esq.
Dear Sir
Enclosed Cape was
sent to your residence yesterday but
Messenger who had route was suddenly
taken ill & took it home with him &
held it until now.  We have discharged
boy for not returning Msg sooner.
Respt Yours
G Sr? Felton Mgr
Ohgo? 9/5/81

Chicago, August 8, 1881
Dear Mama
I write this letter
on your birthday.
I hope that you 
will pass this day
most pleasantly. -
Yesterday papa
drove out with us
to Riverside, where we had a splendid time, run = 
ning about in the grass and gathering
flowers and nuts.

Then we drove to
Mr. Reissig,who
has a beautiful
house and garden
and the finest
toys I have ever
seen, all moving
about naturally.  
a peacock, two
bears and a dog.
From there we went 
to Waldheim and
to Oak Park (Harlem)
where we sat in
a fine garden
and ate some
supper.  The wea
ther was beauti=

ful.  Walther slept
on the way home,
where we arrived
at 9 o'clock.  Ta?
says the we
did behave ike
very good chil=
dren.  Now, dear
Mama, I bid you
good bye.  We all
wish to see you
soon back at
home.  Your
Anna.
The is, of course only a specimen of Annie's handwriting
in English.  She did not, by any means, compose the letter
but only copied it.  However, she read it from my
draft with scarcely any hesitation and not only understands
every word of it, but is able to render it into German quite fluently.

August 9, 1881? 
11/1881
This, then is the 12th anniversary of our
wedding and the first one, upon which we are
apart from each other.  It is a fit occasion
to grow sentimental about and revive all the
sweet memories this day brings up.  But perhaps
it is better for each of us to go over those
memories singly.  The past, the present and the
future wear a different aspect to a woman
of 33 and to a man of 54 years of age.  You
are now on the very print? to accomplish your
full maturity and to become a strong, healthy, lusty
woman with a fine vista upon a life of happi
ness and usefulness after I shall have been re-
moved from a life which has become stale and
dreary to me.  You, as yet live towards the 
future, while I only live towards the past.  
ut in thinking over the last twelve years I
find in my heart nothing but love and grati
tude for you.  I unclear you for the happiness you
have bestowed upon me and think that what
little so every be left of my life will be
devoted to your present and future happiness.
Your unclear letter and printed card from Xesseu?
were received last night.  Why did you adress them to
our house, instead of to the office?  I would get your letters
at least six hours sooner, if directed to the office.  I feel
badly about Eddy's health, but your telegram reissues me
somewhat.  However I am quite impatient to learn when and
in whose company, if any, you have gone to Tranzembad?, and
what are your further plans.  Telegrams only whet the appetite
without satisfying it. Oh, how I long to be with you if only for an
hour.  And yet, it is better as it is - and this temporary separation will
be greatly beneficial to you.  Only - don't forget "Wohin?" yours truly
H.R.

My dear Mama.
I was just writing a story
and papa said I should write
you a letter.  Today papa says
it was just 100 days since you
left Chicago and 35 days more
he expects your here.  We are all
very glad to see you here
in Chicago.  We hope you will
be as well as we were all the 
time.  It is very warm today.  
I only write you this letter
today for the last time in
English since you will leave
Dessau.

Letter from all
Three children & Their
governess to H.R. for his
birthday.  He had taken
his wife to Tennessee for
his health! 1881

Nov. 1869
This letter doesn't
say much - Tho Sophie
& Matilde are both
still there.  She 
does mention Three Chicago?
Parks: Lincoln on the
North Side; Hyde Park
on the South; West Park
on West Side

last p from H R - 
how happy +
in love They are

M. R. describes what
a pleasure it is to 
cook with all
the practical 
kitchen utensils
available.  That 
her husband brought
her a new type of
beater which
unclear  Things much
faster than The
older one.  It 
was a unclear
wheel which turns?
the beaters!!!

NIGHT MESSAGE.
THE WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH COMPANY.
This Company TRANSMITS and DELIVERS messages only on conditions limiting its liability, which have been assented to by the sender of the following message.  
Errors can be guarded against only by? repeating a message back to the sending station for comparison, and the company will not hold itself liable for errors or delays in
transmission or delivery of Unrepeated Night Messages sent at reduced rates, beyond a sum equal to ten times the amount paid for the transmission; nor in any case where
the claim is not presented in writing within thirty days after sending the message.  
This is an UNREPEATED NIGHT MESSAGE, and is delivered by request of the sender, under the conditions named above.  
THOS. T. ECKERT, General Manager.
NORVIN GREEN, President.

"love letter" - 
Grete compares H.R's
reasonable, considerate
manner To his 
family to that?
of? Katz bauseu? ( I
wish? he was a 
Bayou Katzhauseu? 
who shows himself

when he goes down-

Aug 9, 1883
Affectionate letter to H R from?
his wife - says she won't write
again because he will have
left for home before a later
letter would arrive. - Doesn't
know about sending a cable
to the ship before departure
because of uncertainty on account
of the strike!

on the goose an other good things you are having now.
The "general-consul" at our table (you
know who he is, don't you?) speaks of
you quite after, which is a very great
honor to you - at least he thinks 
so.  Other people ask about you too.
The weather is good and I have be=
gun to take morning walks now before 
breakfast (6.30 - 7.30).  I wonder how
long that fit will last?!
Our French isn't improving very 
much, I'm afraid we have reached
the climax now and won't learn
much more. 
Yours, with love,
Annie

Lieber? unclear! Given? the unclear
unclear.  There are four cases
already in Berlin and I am afraid
the disease will spread.  {If?]] you
do not come quick you will be much
detained by the precautions cities
are taking to prevent travelers
to pass from infected places.  
A few weeks vacation will not
hurt you anyhow.  Yesterday we
were surprised by Guenther?
and went to Chillontogether.  
Whenever you start do not for
get to telegraph from the
place you stay over night, to 
satisfy me.  To-morrow we ex-
pect Mr. Ritsch? and family, who
telegraphed yesterday from Hei-?
delberg.  Bring some of your Books
long and your coats and your
suits.  Do not forget your opera glass.
I am very anxious and shall not 
feel quiet till I have you here
Thursday? 
Mama

7/12/92
July? 
1892
unclear:
Better say it in English!
Nanny? wrote a letter to Anny
where she tells her that you have
been terribly cut up by hearing
from Lilly Meyer that I was
sick.  You played your part
well but now please stop,
and tell Smirnoffs? next
time you go there, that I
am a little better and do not

appear to down hearted.  
Let us finish that lying busi-
ness, but burn those letters, 
this one and the one Sara?
sent you about Nanny's coming 
here, as quick as possible, that (though)
nobody can ever find them.  
I have a severe cold and
headaches as usually I have
every winter.  There was a
heavy snowfall yesterday
and the day before and

we have to run a fire in our
little stove all day long.  
If you prefare? not to come down
here I shall send you some money
to amuse yourself during vacation
in Berlin.  It is only four weeks
later shall return to that
place and really I like better
to have you well there, than 
have you take this long trip
down here, when it is such
unpleasant cold weather.  
Now be a good considerate
boy and decide yourself (upon).

how you have to act.  That is
all for to day as Ed. wrote
yesterday and y the day be-
fore.  With thousand kisses
your
Mama
Of course I wrote to Frau Luff?
that I was not well, because
I was sure if I did not write
it, they would be astonished that
Anna said I was sick in her 
letter to Nanny

Dear boy!  the best way to
send a wreath on Grandma's
birthday the 13th is taking a 
Posftanmeisung" and send 5 Marks
to the Direction of the Central 
Friedhof and ask them to buy
the flowers and put them
there.  Of course you must write
the name, as we did last year
from Dresden.  You must look
in the Directory for finding
the right name, as I am not
sure I have it correctly above.  
(Let) Just received a letter
from tuat? Sophy, where in
she wants you to stay over
Christmas in her house.  
What do you say to it
answer quickly.  
M.

on the 1881 trip - 
The cryptic words
in margin are "code"
worked out for her us
in cables + also
his to her = Her
expenditures are in
later half of booklet?
put with trip
